1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.
1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat.

More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes.

Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying.
A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying. If she can be successfully captured and survive a 500-mile translocation across Niger, she’ll become one of eight founding Adams and Eves of a new population of one of the world’s rarest wild mammals.

He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying. If she can be successfully captured and survive a 500-mile translocation across Niger, she’ll become one of eight founding Adams and Eves of a new population of one of the world’s rarest wild mammals. An orphaned giraffe nuzzles a caregiver at Sarara Camp in northern Kenya.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.

A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen.
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles.
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere.
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance.
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich?
A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002).
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced.
A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe.
A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 .
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years.
A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian. Finally, the last bequest was made in 1429 and confirmed in 1432 by Robert Baxter, a citizen and merchant of Norwich, who left three shillings and four pence to the anchorite at St. Julian’s church in Conisford 5 . The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.

Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.

Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy.

This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well.
ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old.
Addiction has set in.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response.

When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.”
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system.
Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals.

Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs.
Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love.
Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love. This phenomenon is rooted in the brain.
Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love. This phenomenon is rooted in the brain. When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love.

Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere.
All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space.
