Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance?
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance? These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value.
And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance? These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand.

The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance? These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s.

GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches.
And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.

Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.

Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.

The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.

Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.

Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted.
As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group.
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere.
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes).
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other.
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory).
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere.

To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere.
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05).
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION
As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side.
As resignation/despair sets in, the lover gives up hope and slips into depression.
As resignation/despair sets in, the lover gives up hope and slips into depression. Both are linked with the dopamine system in the brain.
As resignation/despair sets in, the lover gives up hope and slips into depression. Both are linked with the dopamine system in the brain. And I suspect that both were deeply embedded in the hominin mind by the time Lucy was loving, perhaps even losing a beloved, long ago.
As resignation/despair sets in, the lover gives up hope and slips into depression. Both are linked with the dopamine system in the brain. And I suspect that both were deeply embedded in the hominin mind by the time Lucy was loving, perhaps even losing a beloved, long ago. When lovers encounter barriers to their romantic feelings, their passion intensifies—what I call frustration-attraction.

And I suspect that both were deeply embedded in the hominin mind by the time Lucy was loving, perhaps even losing a beloved, long ago. When lovers encounter barriers to their romantic feelings, their passion intensifies—what I call frustration-attraction. Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love. This phenomenon is rooted in the brain. When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love.

And I suspect that both were deeply embedded in the hominin mind by the time Lucy was loving, perhaps even losing a beloved, long ago. When lovers encounter barriers to their romantic feelings, their passion intensifies—what I call frustration-attraction. Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love. This phenomenon is rooted in the brain. When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms.

Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died.

The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents.

The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished.

The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died.
