There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches.
Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01).
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01).
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01).
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01).
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere.
Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes).
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two.
Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm.
Behavioral data Mean
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand.
Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.

It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.

The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.

The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.
Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen.
Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443.

In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse.

Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years.
Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.

Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.

In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.

Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn.

First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.

Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection.
Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity.
Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction.

We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured.

This phenomenon is rooted in the brain. When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still).
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition.
Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s.

GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate.
But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.

Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.
