Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002).
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex.
Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233).
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite.
Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite. In the will of 1415 it is said that John Plumpton, a citizen of Norwich, left forty pence to the ankress in ecclesia santi Juliani de Conesford in Norwice and twelve pence each to her serving maid and to her former maid Alice.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation.

The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry.
Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations.
During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe.
During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two.
During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm.

In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.

In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion.

The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner.

For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used.

We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks.

In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine.
During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen.
Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition. The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space.
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS
Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations. Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations. Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites.

This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common.
Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover.

Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem.

This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years.
Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate.

Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.

Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.

Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response.
