The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression.
Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression. Others commit suicide.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells.
It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990).
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand).
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands.
It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects).
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002).
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere.
It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990).
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI.
It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990). Leaving the solution of this chicken and egg problem to future research, we want to note that neither of the two switched groups (even the SS group) was able to conform fully to environmental demands and completely change their hand preferences to full right- handedness. Consequently, their HPIs were significantly lower than those of the group of consistent right-handers. This difference may reflect the importance of inherited factors in shaping brain architecture, which can only undergo plastic changes to a limited extent. Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand).
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.

It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.

The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism.
It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain.
It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side.
