Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered).
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere.
It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999).
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand.
It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999). The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control.
It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing.
It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control.
It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control. It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand.

It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand.
It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control. It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999).

It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.

Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.
It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.

There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love. A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya.
Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion.
Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.
Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.
Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.

This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.

With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.

Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
