Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half.
Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half. The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar).
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions. It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions. It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions. It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control. It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions. It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control. It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand.
Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies. In this choice reaction time paradigm the subjects were expected to react with their left, right, or both hands depending on a presentation of one of three possible visual cues. This task might present special difficulty for the left-handers due to their problems with discrimination between the left and right directions. It seems plausible therefore, that the results obtained by Klöppel and coauthors (2007) are related to decisions regarding the hand choice rather than to monitoring the execution of an automatically performed bar pressing. The finding that, in both the RH and LH groups, movements of the preferred hand lead to greater contralateral activation and movements of the non-preferred hand lead to greater ipsilateral activation implicates the existence of a common mechanism for motor control. It may consist in exerting the motor control by the dominant hemisphere not only over the contralateral (preferred) hand but also over the ipsilateral (nonpreferred) hand. In contrast, the non-dominant hemisphere is involved mainly in the motor control of the contralateral (non-preferred) hand. In other words the preferred hand seems to be controlled mainly by the dominant hemisphere, while the non-preferred hand is controlled by both the dominant and non-dominant hemispheres as has already been suggested by Baraldi and others (1999).
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying. If she can be successfully captured and survive a 500-mile translocation across Niger, she’ll become one of eight founding Adams and Eves of a new population of one of the world’s rarest wild mammals.
Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. An orphaned giraffe nuzzles a caregiver at Sarara Camp in northern Kenya.

An orphaned giraffe nuzzles a caregiver at Sarara Camp in northern Kenya. Samburu cattle herders found the abandoned calf and alerted Sarara—known for raising orphaned stmammals and returning them to their habitat.

An orphaned giraffe nuzzles a caregiver at Sarara Camp in northern Kenya. Samburu cattle herders found the abandoned calf and alerted Sarara—known for raising orphaned stmammals and returning them to their habitat. The young giraffe now lives with a wild herd.

An orphaned giraffe nuzzles a caregiver at Sarara Camp in northern Kenya. Samburu cattle herders found the abandoned calf and alerted Sarara—known for raising orphaned stmammals and returning them to their habitat. The young giraffe now lives with a wild herd. The giraffes we have chased for a week are the descendants of some 50 animals that made their way to the West African country of Niger in the late 1980s, when drought and war pushed them from their habitat in neighboring Mali.
Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion.
Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half.
Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half. The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying.
Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying. If she can be successfully captured and survive a 500-mile translocation across Niger, she’ll become one of eight founding Adams and Eves of a new population of one of the world’s rarest wild mammals.

They walked south-southeast across the Sahel, along the Niger River, and skirted Niamey before settling in the Koure region, on a dry and dusty plateau.

They walked south-southeast across the Sahel, along the Niger River, and skirted Niamey before settling in the Koure region, on a dry and dusty plateau. A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle.

They walked south-southeast across the Sahel, along the Niger River, and skirted Niamey before settling in the Koure region, on a dry and dusty plateau. A Fulani herder named Amadou Hama, 76, recalled what it was like decades ago when he first encountered one of these giraffes one evening while tending his cattle. We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe.
One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.

Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations.

The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.

The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace.
One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation.

The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church.
One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel.
Others commit suicide.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead.

This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction.
Others commit suicide. Surely most rejected lovers feel this sadness during the protest phase as well, but it’s likely to escalate as all hope vanishes. This despair has been associated with several brain networks. Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education.
Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen. CONCLUSIONS To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich?
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral).
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations. Consequently, in right-handers there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation, whereas in left-handers there was a predominance of right-hemisphere activation; although in the latter case, the asymmetry was smaller.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations. Consequently, in right-handers there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation, whereas in left-handers there was a predominance of right-hemisphere activation; although in the latter case, the asymmetry was smaller. Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar).
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations. Consequently, in right-handers there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation, whereas in left-handers there was a predominance of right-hemisphere activation; although in the latter case, the asymmetry was smaller. Notably, these effects were specific to complex rather than simple tasks (during simple tasks the activations elicited by either hand were similar). This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks.
Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations. This concords with the previous observations by Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and others (2005) who also found handedness-related differences onlyfor complex tasks. Finding by Klöppel and colleagues (2007) that the cortical sensorimotor representation may depend on hand preference in simple bar pressing movements could be associated with the experimental procedure which differed considerably from that usedin other studies.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry

Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded. Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded. Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded. Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded. Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences.
Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry Hand preference is the most prominent behavioral expression of brain asymmetry in man. The majority (approximately 90%) of the human population is righthanded. Despite a long history of research on the neurobiological origin of handedness and common believe that it is strongly linked to the brain asymmetry (Grabowska et al. 1994), the neural correlates of hand preferences are still a matter of debate. The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand.
PAD
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere.
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere.
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05).
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side.
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain.
Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral).

No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate.

Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.

She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.

Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed.
Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry.
Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere.
Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space.
