Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05).
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral).
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations.
Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups. This concords with several previous studies and could be related to the fact that most ofthe motor fibers cross within the pyramidal tract. Regarding the main question of the effect of hand preference on hemispheric asymmetry, our study revealed that both in left-handers and right-handers, movements of the preferred hand (right in RH and left in LH) produced larger contralateral activations than movements of the non-preferred hand. In contrast to this, movement of the non-preferred hand, led to larger ipsilateral activations. Consequently, in right-handers there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation, whereas in left-handers there was a predominance of right-hemisphere activation; although in the latter case, the asymmetry was smaller.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements.
Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere. Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved. Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007).
She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.

The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry.
She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations.
She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers. Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers. Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her.
She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers. Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233).
She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her.
She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI.

Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall.
She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God.

Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST.

Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich.

St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite.
She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.

Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful.

A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.

Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days.

He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine.

Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying.
She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.
She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.

Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction.
Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects).
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002).
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group.
Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01).
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01).
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01).
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted.
Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere.
Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI.
Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand).
Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands.
Similar conclusion was drawn by the authors of two previous studies performed on converted left-handers, using functional MRI. The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand).
