Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half.
The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half. The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002).
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement.
The advances in functional neuroimaging techniques have allowed the cortical representation of movements to be measured directly. The neuroimaging studies that have focused on the brain correlates of hand preference have attributed this behavioral asymmetry to hemispheric lateralization of the cortical areas controlling motor function. There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand).
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation. It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation. It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation. It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation. It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
The advantage of our study consists in testing the effects of handedness on brain activation pattern using separate recordings for hand and hemisphere (ipsilateral or contralateral to the moving hand). In theprevious fMRi studies the authors either used the paradigm which did not allow for making such comparison (Siebner et al. 2002) or simply disregarded those factors (Klöppel et al. 2007) focusing on identification of brain regions where converted left-handers showed a consistent difference in task related BOLD signal across all movement conditions and hands. Such approach did not allow them to focus on the mechanisms which, as we have shown, may differ for ipsilateral vs contralateral activation patterns. The observation that in the two switched (SS and SU) groups it was the patterns of ipsilateral and not contralateral activation which resembled that found in the RH and LH groups might suggest that the ipsilateral motor representation is more prone to undergo reorganization due to educational training than the contralateral one. Testing this interesting possibility, however, requires more specific further investigation. It is widely known that individual subjects, whether they are right- or left-handed, differ considerably as to their specific pattern of handedness. In this study, we attempted to directly relate behavioral differences (individual profiles of hand preference) to individual patterns of activation in the two hemispheres. In other words the question was whether individual patterns of organization of motor control in the brain constitute a continuum that corresponds directly with a continuum of individual patterns of hand preferences. Our data revealed a significant correlation between total activation in the left hemisphere and the handedness preference index (HPI) that indicates that the stronger the right hand preference, the larger the total volume of activation in the left hemisphere. A similar relationship between hand preference index and the anatomical parameters has been demonstrated by Amunts and coauthors (1996, 2000) in the primary sensorimotor and by Klöppel and others (2010) in the left middle putamen.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.

Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies.
The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere. The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent.

The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group.

The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand.

The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself.
The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies.
The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent.
The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion.

This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand.
The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance.

Who was Julian of Norwich?

Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well.
