Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old.
The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand.
The conclusion that in the right-handers the left hemisphere plays a dominant role in motor control is consistent with clinical evidence demonstrating that limb apraxia is more common after left hemisphere damage than after right hemisphere damage and disrupts motor skills even when the left, ipsilesional hand is used by the patients. This conclusion also conforms the anatomical data showing structural asymmetries in the central sulcus (larger surfaces of dorsolateral motor cortex in the dominant hemisphere) in right-handers and left-handers. Interestingly, recent clinical study on right-handed patients with unilateral paretic stroke (Rinehart et al. 2009) provided further observation, which perfectly matches our findings. In this study the authors assessed the relative use of the right, left and both arms with wrist accelerometers. The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.

Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent.
The disadvantages of this experimental design were that the authors were neither able to compare brain activity during dominant and nondominant hand movements (which, according to the previously mentioned papers, is critical for detecting hand preference-related differences), nor to make direct comparison between left- and right-hand writers as scanning in the two groups was performed for different hands. In a more recent study Klöppel and colleagues (2007) studied the localization of movement related activity with fMRI while converted left-handers and age-matched groups of consistent left handers and righthanders pressed a button with their right, left or both hands depending on which of three symbolic visual cues was presented. The authors have found two regions of increased activity in converted left-handers as compared to either consistent left-handers or righthanders: one in sensorimotor and premotor cortex in the left hemisphere and the other in inferior parietal cortex of the right hemisphere. The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.

The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.
