The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007).
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features.
The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.
The evidence of these wills clearly demonstrates that Julian must have been a highly esteemed personality in her town. Francis Blomfield, the Norfolk antiquarian, leaves us a report that in the 18th century Julian’s anchorhold did not exist anymore, but was razed to the ground during the dissolution of monasteries. Besides, in his History of Norwich, he gives us some precious information about the anchoress herself: In the east part of this Church-yard stood an Anchorage, in which an Ankress or Recluse dwelt ’til the Dissolution, when the house was demolished, tho’ the Foundations may still be seen. In 1393, Lady Julian the Ankress here, was a strict Recluse, and had 2 servants to attend her in her old age, A o 1443. This woman in those Days was esteemed one of the Greatest Holynesse. The date of 1443, furnished by Blomfield, seems surprising. It would imply that Julian who was born in 1342 lived for more than a hundred years. Julian scholars usually discard this information as not very trustworthy, and explain that he confused our Julian with another recluse that lived here after Julian had died and who took the same name after the patron saint of the Church, St. Julian. Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side.
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered).
The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered.

Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable.
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01).
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01).
The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand. Significant group activations during simple movements were found in: precentral, postcentral, parietal superior, parietal inferior and supramarginal gyri, all exclusive to the hemisphere contralateral to the moving hand. For complex movements, activation covered much broader areas including the cerebral cortex (precentral gyrus, postcentral gyrus, supplementary motor area, insula, cingulum, parietal lobuli, supramarginal, superior and medial temporal gyri), subcortical areas (putamen, pallidum, the thalamus) in both the contralateral and ipsilateral hemispheres for either hand. In addition, cerebellar activations (mainly ipsilateral) were registered. Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01).
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics. Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance?
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance? These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value.

In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner. The present study addressed the following questions: (1) what are the differences in the organization of motor control in the brain between left-and righthanders, (2) does motor task complexity influence those differences, (3) do early switch of hand preference, due to social pressure, leads to long-lasting changes in brain organization, and (4) does the organization of motor function patterns in the brain reflect handedness preference and performance? These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand.

The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study.

Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent.
The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand.
