These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite. In the will of 1415 it is said that John Plumpton, a citizen of Norwich, left forty pence to the ankress in ecclesia santi Juliani de Conesford in Norwice and twelve pence each to her serving maid and to her former maid Alice.
The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich. In one of these, dated March 1393, it is said that the rector of St. Michael’s Church at Coslany in Norwich, Roger Reed, left two shillings to Julian anakorite. In the will of 1415 it is said that John Plumpton, a citizen of Norwich, left forty pence to the ankress in ecclesia santi Juliani de Conesford in Norwice and twelve pence each to her serving maid and to her former maid Alice. A year later, in 1416, the Countess of Suffolk, Isabel Ufford, left a bequest of twenty shillings to Julian.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered).
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups.
The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.

Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.

Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation.
The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate. Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com. Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately.
The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns.
The increased activation in the left hemisphere was interpreted as a consequence of educationally induced high daily practice in right hand writing of that originally left- handed group. The persisting activity in their right inferior parietal cortex was taken as en evidence that the involvement of higher order associative areas in the originally dominant hemisphere is invariant and cannot be switched to the opposite hemisphere due to educational training. Importantly enough, this study did not consider the possible relationship between the ipsi- vs. contralateral activations and the handedness factor, neither it directly compared the activations in the two hemispheres elicited by either hand. Moreover, due to simplicity of the movement (just pressing a button), the task focused more on taking a decision which hand should be used, than on movement execution control itself. And this might require quite different neural circuits than finger tapping or writing used in previous studies. This short review of the literature demonstrates that the existing data relating the functional brain architecture of motor function to handedness is highly inconsistent. The failure to obtain consistent findings in these studies can be attributed to several factors, with the heterogeneity of the left-handed groups, the low numbers of participating individuals and the selection of divergent motor tasks being the most likely sources of confusion. In the present study we used two different unpracticed motor tasks, one simple and one complex, that have been most commonly used in previous research on the brain’s representation of motor function and can be performed with either hand. This enabled us: (1) to relate our data to the existing literature on motor control, (2) to provide data for both preferred and nonpreferred hand, and (3) to estimate the effect of task complexity on handedness-related differences in activation patterns. The volumes of activation in ipsilateral and contralateral hemispheres obtained in left-handers as well as converted left- handers were compared to those obtained in right-handers who were tested in our previous study (Gut et al. 2007) using the same procedure and scanner.
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand.
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study.
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent.
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI.
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia.

Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University.

Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971).
The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated.
The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity.
The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction.
The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction. We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured.

When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest.

The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help.

Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion.

The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection.
