The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations. Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations. Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures.
The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand. In righthanders, there was a general predominance of left-hemisphere activation relative to right hemisphere activation. In lefthanders this pattern was reversed. The switched subjects showed no such volumetric asymmetry. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity resulted in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations. In both right- and left-handers, movements of the preferred hand activated mainly the contralateral hemisphere, whereas movements of the non-preferred hand resulted in a more balanced pattern of activation in the two hemispheres, indicating greater involvement of the ipsilateral activations. Overall, this study shows that in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the non-preferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left-handers and right-handers regarding their motor control architectures. Key words: left-handedness, motor control, fMRI, brain plasticity, hemispheric asymmetry
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues.
The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still).
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects.
The selection of subjects for either the SS or the SU group was based on their hand preference profile. Individuals showing the HPI>20 (as in the RH group) were selected for the SS group, whereas the individuals showing the HPI<20 (as in the LH group) were selected for the SU group. Following other studies (Annett 2002), we used the HPI score of 20 as the demarcation line between left- and right-handedness because it is thought that the brain organization of individuals with slight preferences toward the right side resembles that typical for left- handers rather than for right-handers. Thus, people with slight right preferences are, to some extent, considered to be left-handers who adapted their behavior to the demands of the right-shifted environment. Brain imaging The experimental paradigm consisted of two experimental runs that each contained 10 alternating blocks of 3 conditions: (A) a simple movement task (flexion/extension of the index finger), (B) a complex movements task (sequential opposition of the thumb to tips of other fingers in the order: 5, 4, 3, 2, 5, 4 and so on), and (C) a rest period (during which the subjects were required to remain still). Within each run, the blocks were repeated in the sequence CABCABCABC. Each block lasted 15 s for a total 2 min 30 s per run. Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster.
The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters.
The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant.
The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
The squares remained visible during each condition.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
The squares remained visible during each condition. Before scanning the subjects were instructed how to react to each stimulus type that they would see on the screen. Stimuli were back-projected from a multi-media projector on a screen located approximately 3 meters away from the magnet. The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere.
The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space.

These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS

The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres. Thus, our strategy was to quantify hemispheric asymmetries in the spatial extent of hand representation by computing the volume of all significantly activated voxels in either hemisphere. These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers.

In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers. What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand?
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers. What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers. What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand.
The study demonstrated that the use of the ipsilateral but not contralateral limb after unilateral stroke was influenced by hand preference: the right hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, right (preferred) limb more than the left-hemisphere damaged patients used their ipsilateral, left(non-preferred) limb and more than healthy righthanders. In other words the damage to the left hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the left hand more than the damage to the right hemisphere impaired the motor abilities of the right hand. This might suggest that in right-handers the involvement of the left (dominant) hemisphere in ipsilateral (left hand) motor control is greater than the involvement of the right hemisphere in the ipsilateral (right hand) motor control. This nicely concords our findings which showed the involvement of the left hemisphere in both the contralateral and ipsilateral motor control in right-handers. Those findings also agree to our conclusion that the right hemisphere in right-handers is mainly involved inthe contralateral (left hand) control and thus, damage to this hemisphere does not have so much negative impact on the use of the right hand as does the damage to the left hemisphere on the use of the left hand. Those data also conform the general conclusion regarding the dominance of the left hemisphere in motor control in right-handers. What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971).
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2).
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20.
The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20. The two latter groups (SS and SU) consisted of subjects who had been forced in childhood to switch their original lefthand preferences toward the right side resulting in the use of their right hands for writing.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap.
The study was performed using a 1.5 T Signa Horizon MR system. The functional MRI images were acquired using an interleaved gradient-echo echoplanar (EPI) sequence sensitive to the blood oxygenation level dependent (BOLD) contrast with the following parameters: 3 000/60 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 90º flip angle, a 18 × 13 cm field ofview (FOV), a 96 × 64 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to one. In plane resolution was 1.41 × 1.41mm. During each functional scanning session 50 sets of 10 contiguous, 7 to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. For each subject, all sections were set parallel to the axis connecting the anterior commissure and the caudal surface of the cerebellar tonsil and extended right up to the posterior midline boundary of the parietal lobe. The selected slice-thickness was adjusted to each subject’s brain volume. Coplanar, high-resolution structural MRI images were acquired for the same locations as the functional images using a SPoiled GRadient-echo (SPGR) sequence with the following parameters: 50/6 (repetition time ms/echo time ms), a 60º flip angle, a 18 × 13cm FOV, a 256 × 256 matrix, and the number of excitations equal to two. In plane resolution was 0.86× 0.86 mm. Depending on the subject, ten 7- to 10-mm-thick oblique sections were acquired, without any gap. We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion.
The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles.
The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere.
The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.

Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy.

Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
