There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love. A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers. Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value.
There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century. Though Julian lived the hidden life of a recluse, her cell in Norwich has become a source of spiritual enlightenment and comfort for our tormented times as well as for hers. Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her.
There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya.
There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion.
There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half.
There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half. The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002).
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements.
There is, however, a lack of consistency in these authors’ opinions as to the specific manifestation of handedness- related differences. Such differences have been found either in the localization, the volumes or the number of activated areas in the two hemispheres or in the specific presence of ipsilateral activation in the motor control of the preferred vs. non-preferred hand. Moreover, this ipsilateral activation pattern seems to be dependent on such features as movement complexity. In their fMRI study Solodkin and coauthors (2001) found that, during the performance of a sequential finger movement task, left-handers tended to activate larger volumes in a greater number of association cortices and showed less lateralization than did righthanders. A subsequent report by the same authors revealed that right-handers had greater activation in the left premotor area for either hand, indicating a general dominance of the left hemisphere in motor function, whereas the left-handed group showed a predominance of activation in the premotor cortex contralateral to the moving hand (either left or right), indicating no such asymmetry (Hlustik et al. 2002). However, similar comparisons performed by Volkman and colleagues (1998) in a magnetoencephalographic study and by Dassonville and others (1997) in an fMRI study revealed that, in both right- and left-handers, the use of the preferred hand was associated with a greater volume of activation in the contralateral motor cortex. Several papers have specifically focused on the ipsilateral activation issue based on the observation that in right-handers ipsilateral activation is characteristic of non-preferred (left) hand movements as opposed to preferred hand movement. Singh and coauthors (1998) reported that right handers showed greater activation of the ipsilateral hemisphere in the sensorimotor region for non-preferred (left) hand movements compared to ipsilateral hemisphere activation for preferred (right) hand movements; whereas, in left- handers, such asymmetry was not present. In line with those findings Gut and coworkers (2007) found in right-handed participants the advantage of ipsilateral activation during the left hand movements compared to the right hand movements. Ipsilateral activation was also registered in lefthanded individuals by Kawashima and others (1997), but the effects were present in the premotor and not the motor cortex and in the right and not the left hemisphere.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121. The situation in England was further aggravated by the peasants’ rebellion against the lords, secular and ecclesiastical. The peasants rampaged across the country pillaging castles, churches and monasteries. When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered).
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles.
Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side. Although the differences in brain activation in the two switched (SU and SS) groups were not statistically significant, it is worth noting that the activation patterns of their brains reflected the differences observed at the behavioral level: the SS group was more similar to the RH group, while the SU group resembled the LH group (at least when the pattern of ipsilateral activations was considered). In both groups of converted left-handers, however, the brain organization was more symmetrical than in the two consistent handedness groups. It is a matter of debate whether the hemispheric asymmetry in cortical organization of motor function is a consequence of, or a cause of hand preferences. There are two contradictory explanations that should both be considered; different hand preferences may lead to differences in the amount of left and right hand training and, consequently, to differences in the cortical representation of each hand. It could also be argued that it is the primary difference in brain organization that constitutes the causal factor driving human handedness. The two groups of SU and SS subjects might have been different from an early age as to their hand preference profiles. Their present brain organization patterns could, therefore, be a consequence of those early differences (Harris 1990).
These analyses were run in native subject space.
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities.
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted.
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group.
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study.
These analyses were run in native subject space. RESULTS Behavioral data Mean Handedness Preference Index (HPI) was calculated for each group of subjects and the mean index of handedness are presented in Table I. Noticeably, both the consistent right-handed (RH) and the successfully switched (SS) groups had clearly positive HPI values indicating right-hand preferences in a large range of activities. Lower values of the index in the SS compared to the RH group indicate that the hand preference alteration was not complete, and some features of covert left- handedness persisted. In both consistent left handed (LH) and unsuccessfully switched (SU) groups, the mean HPIs were negative, indicating the predominance of left-hand preferences for the majority of activities and thus an unsuccessful handedness switch in the SU group. Imaging data Localization of activation The fMRI scans revealed a number of areas that were consistently activated during hand movements used in the study. Figure 1 illustrates the localization of significant activations in the four groups of subjects for simple and complex movements performed with the right or left hand.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies.

Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting.
These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University.

Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects.
These issues are interesting not only from theoretical point of view, but they also have clinical value. The knowledge on brain activation patterns in subgroups that differ in hand preference might help to make proper decisions as to which hand should be chosen forwriting in individual cases in which the preference is not obvious and in those who have used the non-preferred hand for a long time after injury of the originally preferred hand. Fifty-two healthy subjects (24 males and 28 females) between 17 and 36 years of age (mean = 22.1 years; SD= 5. 3) participated in the study. All participants were informed about the purpose of the study before giving their written consent. None of the participants had any contraindications to MRI. No participants reported neurological or psychiatric illnesses, learning disabilities, failures in elementary school or claustrophobia. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee of Jagiellonian University. Handedness assessment To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971).
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns.
These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity.

The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training.
