We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help.

The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion.

Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction. We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects.
Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image. To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory).
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05).
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain.
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral).
To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere. Higher HPIs (i. e. stronger right hand preference) were associated with larger volume of activation in the left hemisphere. Separate analyses for the simple and complex movements revealed that this correlation was only significant for complex movements(r=0. 34, P<0. 05). DISCUSSION This study examined the volume of left and right hemisphere activations during hand movements in right-handers, left-handers and originally left-handed individuals who, during their childhood, received pressure to switch hand preference toward the right side. Our goal was to clarify issues related to the brain mechanisms of hand preference and, specifically, to investigate the effect of switching hand preferences on the organization of motor control in the brain. In contrast to previous studies, we controlled for the potential influences of several factors that are suspected to play a role in the brain activation pattern while subjects perform manual tasks: type of movement (simple vs. complex), hand performing the movement (preferred vs. non-preferred) and the activated hemisphere (ipsilateral vs. contralateral). The most obvious finding of our study was that, for both hands and tasks, the contralateral activations were larger than the ipsilateral activations in all groups.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971).
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2).
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20. The two latter groups (SS and SU) consisted of subjects who had been forced in childhood to switch their original lefthand preferences toward the right side resulting in the use of their right hands for writing.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20. The two latter groups (SS and SU) consisted of subjects who had been forced in childhood to switch their original lefthand preferences toward the right side resulting in the use of their right hands for writing. In all cases interviews provided detailed information about the conversion process.
To assess individual profiles of handedness we measured the direction and degree of hand preference in all subjects. For this purpose subjects completed the 10-point Edinburgh Handedness Inventory (Oldfield 1971). For each subject, a Handedness Preference Index (HPI) ranging from +100 for extreme righthanders to −100 for extreme left-handers was calculated. The participants were divided into four groups: consistent right-handers (RH, n=12), consistent left-handers (LH, n=17), switched successfully (SS, n=11) and switched unsuccessfully (SU, n=2). The former two groups (LH and RH) consisted of subjects who reported consistent left- or right-hand preferences across their lives and no attempts at rightward shifts during childhood. All individuals in the group of consistent left-handers used their left hand for writing and had a handedness preference index (HPI)<20. Individuals in the group of consistent right-handers used their right hand for writing and had a HPI>20. The two latter groups (SS and SU) consisted of subjects who had been forced in childhood to switch their original lefthand preferences toward the right side resulting in the use of their right hands for writing. In all cases interviews provided detailed information about the conversion process. All unclear cases were excluded.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01).
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes).
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory).
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere.
To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere. The reverse pattern of activation emerged in the LH group: larger contralateral activations were elicited by the left (preferred) hand, and larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by the right (non- preferred) hand (both leading to larger total activation in the right hemisphere, however the differences between hands were not significant for contralateral or ipsilateral activation volumes). In the two switched (SS and SU) groups the pattern of ipsilateral activations resembled those found in the RH and LH groups, respectively; whereas the contralateral activations for either hand did not differ from each other. To analyze a possible relationship between brain activation patterns and behavioral lateralization patterns, total volumes of activation in each hemisphere were correlated with HPI index (assessed by the Oldfield Inventory). Pearson correlation procedures for the entire sample of subjects (raw data from individual subjects from all four groups) revealed a significant positive correlation (r=0.31, P<0. 05) between the HPI and the total amount of activation in the left hemisphere. No such relationship was found for the right hemisphere.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile.
To remove low frequency artifacts, a high-pass temporal filter was applied to the functional images by using a straight line fitting with a cutoff at 45 s. Gaussian spatial smoothing with an FWHM kernel of 8 mm was carried out on the functional images to reduce noise. In the statistical analysis, linear contrasts on between conditions at the subject level were calculated in native subject space as a pre-step to the higher-level analyses. Higher level group analyses were performed by first registering the subject-level contrast images to a reference brain in Talairach standard space (Roland andZilles 1994); next FLAME (FMRIB’s Local Analysis of Mixed Effects) was used on the contrast images to estimate the inter-subject random-effects. Each group’scross-subject variance was estimated separately. The statistical Z-images from the group analysis were thresholded at z=3.3 to obtain clusters. All clusters with a P≤0.05 were considered significant. As a final step, the intersection volumes between significant clusters and cytoarchitectonically defined regions were calculated. Previous reports suggest that the localization of particular brain areas associated with motor function may vary across subjects and that the particular regions need not to be the same size in the left and right hemispheres, especially when the sample varies in handedness profile. Taking this variation into consideration, we decided rather to assess the general roles of left or right hemisphere in motor control by calculating the total volume of the activated areas in the left/right – contralateral/ipsilateral hemispheres.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy.
To sum up, in both left- and right-handed subjects, the preferred hand is controlled mainly by the hemisphere contralateral to that hand, whereas the nonpreferred hand is controlled by both hemispheres. The switched individuals share features of both left- handersand right-handers regarding their motor control architecture and hand preference profiles. Increasing levels of complexity of motor activity results in an increase in the volume of consistently activated areas and the involvement of the ipsilateral in addition to contralateral activations, especially in the dominant hemisphere. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS The authors thank prof. Terrence Hines for his valuable comments on the first draft of this paper and Barbara Sobiecka and Justyna Kozub for technical assistance. This study was supported by a grant no. 1 H01F056 27 from the Polish State Committee for Scientific Research and grant no. 2011/03/B/HS6/05161 from the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education. Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233).
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich.
Today she is considered one of the giants of western spirituality whose writings possess universal and permanent value. She is truly the spiritual Mother of England, as the first editor of her Showings, the Benedictine Father Serenus Cressy, called her. Despite the fact that Julian has not been officially canonised by the Catholic Church – the Anglican Church venerates her as blessed on May 8 –, the new Catechism of the Catholic Church explicitly acknowledges her holiness as it presents her, along with St. Catherine of Siena and St. Thomas More, as those saints who witness to the truth that God works with those who love him and turns everything to their good (Rm 8, 28) and quotes the following passage from her Showings: And in this way I was taught by the grace of God that I ought to keep myself steadfastly in the faith and that I should stand firm and believe firmly that every kind of thing will be well… You will see yourself that every kind of thing will be well (LT 233). The greatest acknowledgment, though, on the part of the Catholic Church was granted to Mother Julian by the present Holy Father, Benedict XVI. Continuing with his series on great women of the Church, the Pontiff gave a catechesis on the figure of this English mystic in his Wednesday audience on December 1, 2010, held in the Paul VI Hall. He pointed out, above all, her vocation as a spiritual mother to the many people who sought her counsel, and the immeasurable optimism that irradiates from her message on the tender and motherly love of God. St. Julian made an account of her Revelations in two writings, known as the Short Text and the Long Text. Henceforth, the Long Text will be referred to throughout the book as LT, and the Short Text as ST. Throughout the text the quotations will be taken from the modern version of Julian’s Revelations, based on the critical text, by E. Colledge – J. Walsh, Julian of Norwich. There are some bequests in wills that were probably made to her to support her living as an anchoress at St. Julian’s Church in Norwich.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half.
Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries. Northern giraffes lack spots on the lower legs. Reticulated giraffes get their name from their clearly defined patches. There is some evidence that their numbers— although low—are stabilizing in Kenya. Of the four main species, Masai giraffes have the darkest complexion. Thirty years ago this species was the most populous, but it’s since been reduced by half. The southern giraffe is at the least risk.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained.
Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents. It is estimated that more than a third of the population perished. There were many who considered the plague an eschatological sign of divine retribution. The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation.
