The impression that apocalyptic times were at the doors was strengthened by the longest conflict in the history of warfare, lasting from 1337 to 1453. It was a conflict for the French throne between the royal house of Valois who claimed the title of King of France, and the house of Anjou from England, who claimed to be both Kings of England and of France, since they had their roots in the French regions of Anjou and Normandy. The English invasion was initially very successful in gaining new territories and much plunder, but after the involvement of St. Joan of Orleans in the battle and the solemn crowning of Charles VII as king of France at Reims, they lost eventually much of what had been gained. And though the war was fought mostly on the continent, the continuous suffering and the casualties flung both countries into deeper depression and privation. 1 Cf. C. Creighton, A History of Epidemics in Britain, vol. 1, New York 1965 2 , 121.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007).
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities.
Two other studies pointed to similarities in the motor control of left- and right- handers: bothgroups had stronger ipsilateral activations in the motor cortex of the left hemisphere compared to the right hemisphere. The only difference (revealed by Verstynenand coworkers in 2005) was that, in left-handers, the hemispheric asymmetries were less pronounced. The divergence of the obtained results increases if one takes into account the type of motor tasks performed by the subjects in these studies. Specifically, it is not clear whether differences between left- and right-handers apply to motor behavior in general or are predominantly linked to more complex motor tasks involving sequential component in the movements. Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating.
Unfortunately, these data could not be contrasted with data from right-handers, as no appropriate control group was involved.

Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities.
Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif.
Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese.
Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit.
Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. The anti-Wycliffite persecutions took place also in Norwich, supported by the warlike bishop Despenser who swore to put to death by flame or by decapitation any of the dissenters who might presume to preach in his diocese. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time.
Unfortunately, this Constitution prohibited also the use of the Bible and theological writings in English by lay people, seeing in it an association with the heresy of Wyclif. Julian might have been a silent witness of their execution at a place known as the Lollard Pit. The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there.

The city of Norwich, built around the River Wensum and located in the county of Norfolk near the coast of East Anglia, was an important port and England’s second largest city boasting 10, 000-12, 000 inhabitants in Julian’s time. It was a flourishing centre of trade and religious life, attracting a number of religious orders and movements, including Lollards, who set up their houses there. This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today.

It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day.

This Rome of England, as Norwich used to be called in the medieval times, had 57 churches inside the city wall, of which 31 still exist today. It confirms a popular saying that the city had: A church for every week and a pub for every day. It is in this historical context that Julian of Norwich receives extraordinary visions on God’s love towards all people. Amidst all the calamities raging around, her book of revelations, or Showings, as she herself often calls them, must have had a counter-cultural and revolutionary impact. With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.
Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.
Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.

A Texas taxidermy shop displays a fresh giraffe trophy. Cardboard strips and pins hold the skin in place while it dries on a giraffe-shaped styrofoam form. Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild. Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.

Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days.

Of all the large African mammals that wildlife veterinarian Pete Morkel has had to capture over his career—lions, forest elephants, white rhinos—giraffes are the most stressful. With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine.
Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction.
Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years.
Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course. Modern data suggest that romantic love should be treated as an addiction, regardless of its lack of official diagnostic classification as an addiction. The human animal seems driven by a tide of feelings that ebb and flow to an internal beat, a rhythm that emerged when our ancestors first descended from the trees of Africa and developed a tempo to their relationships that was in synchrony with their natural breeding cycle—three to four years. Perhaps the brain’s systems for dopamine, vasopressin, oxytocin, and other neurochemicals orchestrate this rhythm, escalating when you fall in love, changing as you begin to feel deep attachment and cosmic union, then eventually becoming desensitized or overloaded, leading to indifference or restlessness that slowly eats your love and leads to separation—a hardship that can trigger the mother of all addictions, addiction to a mate.

Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute.

Dr. Helen Fisher is a biological anthropologist and senior research fellow at The Kinsey Institute. She has written five internationally best-selling books on love and personality and is currently Chief Scientific Advisor to Match.com.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side.

Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks.

Excerpted from the book Anatomy of Love: A Natural History of Mating, Marriage, and Why We Stray © 2016 by Helen Fisher, published by W. W. Norton on Feb. 1, 2016. Echo-planar MR imaging was performed in 52 subjects: consistent right- handers (RH), consistent left-handers (LH), and subjects who had been forced at an early age to switch their left-hand preferences toward the right side. The scanning was performed during simple (flexion/extension of the index finger) and complex (successive finger-thumb opposition) tasks. Subjects performed the tasks using both the preferred and non-preferred hand.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching.
Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world. Julian Fennessy, co-director of the Giraffe Conservation Foundation (GCF), calls this the silent extinction,  because unlike the attention lavished on the disappearance of elephants and great apes, most people assume that giraffes are doing just fine in the wild, perhaps because of their abundance in zoos and as stuffed animals. GIRAFFES IN DANGER Some 110, 000 giraffes roam throughout Africa, down from a million in the 1700s. Scientists had long believed that all giraffes belonged to a single species, but new DNA research has identified four distinct species. Top threats to giraffes include habitat fragmentation, deforestation, war, and poaching. The Kordofan and Nubian, subspecies of northern giraffes, are most threatened, living mainly in war-torn countries.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards.
Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church. He attacked the misuse of indulgences, criticized the ecclesiastical hierarchy for seeking power and wealth, and desired that the Church return to the primitive simplicity of the Gospel. Besides, he supported the translations of the Bible into the English vernacular so that common people could understand it. Scarcely a decade after Wyclif’s death a bull was issued by Boniface IX, 1396, against Wyclif’s followers, called the Lollards. In England they started to be fiercely persecuted and this culminated in the Constitutions (1407-1408) of the Archbishop of Canterbury and Chancellor of England, Thomas Arundel, who labelled them as traitors and heretics.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007).
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors.
Using simple and complex movements, Solodkin and coauthors (2001) and Verstynen and colleagues (2005) found handedness-related differences only for complex tasks, however, differences have also been reported for relatively simple tasks (Volkman et al. 1998, Klöppel et al. 2007). These findings points to the importance of controlling for task complexity in future studies. Questions about the brain correlates of motor control in case of forced right-handedness are another interesting issue concerning the effect of hand-preference on the organization of motor function in the brain. Many individuals, especially in older generation, report that they had experienced considerable pressure to switch their hand preference from left toright. Switch attempts may proceed either nearly free of problems and lead to a change in the child’s hand preference for a wide range of everyday activities, including writing; or switch attempts may bring much difficulty and result in a switch of preferences for only few activities. These specific activities are likely to include the specific targets of forced right-handednes such as writing, drawing or eating. Taken these facts together, the question follows whether early changes of hand preference behaviors due to environmental pressure exerted upon originally left-handed individuals lead to changes in brain organization toward a more right-handed” brain, or do these people still preserve left handed” brain features. The first possibility seems more plausible in light of many brain plasticity studies showing that the human brain is capable of substantial reorganization due to experience, and sensorimotor training. However, the latter possibility cannot be excluded because the lateralization of brain function seems to be strongly genetically driven and, thus, heavily dependent on innate factors. Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting.
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable.
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01).
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01).
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01).
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted.
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere.
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance.
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01).
Volumes of hemispheric activation in relation to handedness and task complexity Because the aim of the study was to determine whether the motor networks responsible for controlling left and right hand movements in the ipsilateraland contralateral hemispheres were asymmetrically activated and whether this effect depended on the hand preference and complexity of the task, the data were subjected to analysis of variance (ANOVA) that used group (RH, LH, SU and SS), movement complexity (simple/complex), hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral) and hand (left/right) as the main factors and the volume of activation as the dependent variable. This analysis revealed significant main effects of movement complexity (F1, 48=116.59; P<0.01)and hemisphere (F1, 48=101.54; P<0.01). The result of t-tests indicated a larger volume of activation during complex than simple movement task (t51=11. 2; P<0. 01) and a larger volume of activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral hemisphere (t51=10. 08;P<0. 01). Moreover, the analysis revealed three significant interactions: movement complexity × hemisphere (F1, 48=12. 42; P<0. 01), hand × hemisphere × group (F3, 48=4. 61; P<0. 01) and movement complexity × hemisphere × group × hand (F3, 48=5. 06; P<0. 01). To investigate these interactions, two analyses of variance, separately for simple and complex tasks, using hemisphere (ipsilateral/contralateral), group (RH/LH/SS/US) and moving hand (left/right) as the main factors were conducted. Analysis of the simple movement task data revealed a significant effect of hemisphere (F1, 48=86.23; P<0. 01), indicating larger activation in the contralateral, compared to the ipsilateral, hemisphere. No other factors or interactions reached significance. The same analysis performed for complex task showed a significant main effects of hemisphere (F1, 48 =74.94; P<0.01, with larger contralateral activations) and a significant interaction of group × hand × hemisphere(F3, 48 =6. 34; P<0. 01). As illustratedin Figure 2, during the complex movement task in the RH group, larger contralateral activations were elicited by right (preferred) hand movements than left (non- preferred) hand movements (t11=2. 24; P<0. 05), whereas larger ipsilateral activations were elicited by left (non-preferred) hand movements than the right hand movements (t11=2. 87; P<0. 05), both leading to greater total activation in the left hemisphere.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues.

Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure.

Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon.

Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm.
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004).
We made every effort to ensure subjects were as comfortable as possible to reduce head motion. Subjects were asked to refrain from any movements, not to strain their muscles in any special way (except during the required motor tasks) and not to think about anything in particular while lying in the scanner. A standard radio-frequency (RF) head coil with foam padding to restrict head motion was used. The fMRI experiment was preceded by training ofthe subjects’ on the motor task. Special attention was given to teaching the subjects to pace their movements at approximately twice a second without any preceding cues. Thus, the task was highly automated before the start of the scanning procedure. The images were first converted to the Analyze format with xmedcon. The skull was then removed on the anatomical Analyze images with a probabilistic anisotropic diffusion and multi-scale watershed algorithm. Statistical analyses were performed with FSL 3. 1 (FMRIB Software Library)(Smitch et al. 2004). In the pre-processing step, the functional images were coregistered to the anatomical image.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help.

Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion.

Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence.

He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair.
We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy. When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat.
