More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger.
We thought it was the devil, because of that neck and those horns. People had told me about dangerous animals like lions, but nobody had ever told me about the giraffe. These newly arrived giants were the last survivors of a once vast population of white giraffes whose range at the turn of the last century spanned all of West Africa, from the coast of Senegal to Nigeria. Framed against the Nairobi skyline, giraffes roam Nairobi National Park, four miles from the center of Kenya’s sprawling capital. More than 100 mammal species live in the 45-square-mile park, but Nairobi’s expansion threatens this habitat. In 2016 a team of scientists came to an epiphany (if still contentious) about giraffes. Until then, the conventional view held that all giraffes belonged to a single species, Giraffa camelopardalis. But genetic analysis now suggests that giraffes are in fact four distinct species, actually more different from each other than the brown bear is from the polar bear. And those four species can be further classified into five subspecies, including the rare West African Giraffa camelopardalis peralta, the pale, spotted refugees now found only in the Koure region of Niger. Based on this new taxonomy, all but two subspecies would be considered vulnerable, endangered, or critically endangered, and across Africa, populations have declined by almost 40 percent over the past three decades, leaving an estimated 110, 000 giraffes in the world.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand?
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain.
What could be the functional significance of relatively greater volume of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand? It is reasonable to assume that an increase in the volume of neural tissue engaged in a motor behavior may support the correct execution of that behavior. The expansion of hand motor cortex in the hemisphere contralateral to the dominant hand may thus provide the neural substrate for the more efficient execution of the complex motor activities performed by this hand. The high proficiency in motor control of the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand may then be utilized during the execution of motor tasks not only by the preferred hand but also by the non-preferred one. The finding of higher volumes of activation in the hemisphere contralateral to the preferred hand in both right- and left-handers agrees with a few other functional imaging studies of right- and left-handers. In the present study we also investigated the brain organization patterns of subjects who were originally left-handed, but at the age of 7, were switched to righthandedness. The results showed that switched participants shared features of both left-handers and righthanders. Therefore, it could be speculated that the brains of the originally left-handed subjects underwent plastic changes that consisted in reorganization of their motor function toward the right-handed” brain. This reorganization, however, was not complete and showed persisting features of the left-handed” brain. Interestingly, there was a correspondence between the amount of supposed brain reorganization and the degree to which the individuals changed their hand preferences toward the right side.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction.
When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction. We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured.
When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love.
When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in.

Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response.

Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response.

When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates.

Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards.
When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system.
When a reward is delayed in coming, neurons of the brain’s dopamine system continue their activity—sustaining one’s feelings of intense romantic love. Addiction has set in. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety. Stress elevates this dopamine response. When mammals first experience severe stress, among their bodily reactions is an increase in the activity of central dopamine and norepinephrine and a suppression of central serotonin, known as the stress response. Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals.
When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest.
When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense.
When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help.

Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion.

Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence.

He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair.

Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response.
When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression.
When it is removed from mother and put into the kitchen by itself, it immediately begins to pace, frantically leaping at the door, barking and whining in protest. Isolated baby rats emit ceaseless ultrasonic cries; they hardly sleep because their brain arousal is so intense. The purpose of this protest: to increase alertness and stimulate an abandoned creature to object, search, and call for help. Protest, the stress response, frustration-attraction, abandonment rage, craving, withdrawal symptoms: All play a role in the worldwide incidence of crimes of passion. Like all addictions, romantic love can lead to violence. Eventually, however, the abandoned lover gives up. He or she stops the pursuit of the beloved, ushering in the second general phase of romantic rejection, resignation/despair. During this stage, the rejected one slips into feelings of lethargy, despondency, melancholy, and depression, known as the despair response. In a study of 114 men and women who had been rejected by a partner within the past eight weeks, 40 percent experienced clinically measurable depression. Some broken- hearted lovers even die from heart attacks or strokes caused by their depression.
When lovers encounter barriers to their romantic feelings, their passion intensifies—what I call frustration-attraction.
When lovers encounter barriers to their romantic feelings, their passion intensifies—what I call frustration-attraction. Adversity heightens feelings of romantic love.

Rejected lovers can also suffer from frustration-aggression, what psychologists call abandonment rage.” Even when a rejecting partner departs with compassion and graciously honors his or her responsibilities as a friend or co-parent, many abandoned people oscillate between heartbreak and fury—another response with neural correlates. The primary rage system is closely connected to centers in the prefrontal cortex that anticipate rewards. So as a person begins to realize that an expected reward is in jeopardy, even unattainable, these regions of the prefrontal cortex stimulate the amygdala and trigger rage, a trait that stresses the heart, raises blood pressure, and suppresses the immune system. This rage response to unfulfilled expectations is well known in other mammals. When a cat is petted, for example, it purrs. When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations.

Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way.

One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation.
When the revolt and plundering were finally stopped, it ended in cruel reprisals. One of its leaders, Geoffrey Litster was sentenced to death by the bishop of Norwich, Henry Despenser, at the gallows not far from Julian’s cell. Finally, the Great Schism of 1378-1415 brought one of the greatest spiritual crisis for the Church and medieval society. The quarrel for the true pope between the claimants of Rome and Avignon shook the Church in its very foundations. Urban VI, the roman claimant to the papacy, went so far in his opposition to his rival, Clement, as to organize a crusade against him. He entrusted the leadership and responsibility to bishop Despenser who promised indulgences to those who would support the cause in a military or financial way. Naturally, it ended in disaster. Some of the crusaders were killed, some were captured, and the rest, including the bishop, returned home in disgrace. The failure of the papacy, the corruption of the ecclesial hierarchy, the abuse of indulgences and the crusade itself provoked general distrust in the visible institution of the Church among the faithful on the continent as well as in England, and prepared the ground for the precursors of the Reformation. The XIV century England saw John Wyclif preaching a reform of the Church.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction. We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured.
When this pleasurable stimulation is withdrawn, it sometimes bites. Indeed, romantic passion and abandonment rage have much in common. Both are associated with bodily and mental arousal; both produce obsessive thinking, focused attention, motivation, and goal-directed behaviors; and both cause intense yearning—either for union with or retaliation against the rejecting lover. Moreover, these feelings of romantic love and rage can act in tandem. In a study of 124 dating couples, Bruce Ellis and Neil Malamuth reported that romantic love and anger/upset” react to different kinds of information. The lover’s level of anger/upset oscillates in response to events that undermine the lover’s goals, such as a mate’s infidelity, lack of emotional commitment, or rejection. The lover’s feelings of romantic love fluctuate in response to events that advance the lover’s goals, such as a partner’s visible social support during outings with relatives and friends, or a direct declaration of love and fidelity. Thus, romantic love and anger/upset can operate concurrently, adding intensity to one’s rejection addiction. We must have inherited this protest response, for it stems from a basic mammalian mechanism that gets triggered when any kind of social attachment is ruptured. Take the puppy.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects).
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions.
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002).
Whether the effectiveness of a hand-preference conversion process is somehow related to what happens in the brain is also extremely interesting. It could be predicted that individuals who were more resistant to the alteration of hand preference were also more resistant to reorganization of their brains as compared with the individuals who switched more successfully. In other words, the question is whether changes in the profile of behavioral preferences are reflected in the brain’s functional organization patterns. Studying individuals who underwent attempts to switch toward right handedness and comparing them with consistent left- and right-handers presents an unusual opportunity to gain a better insight into the mechanisms that, on the one side, determine the lateralization of function and, on the other side, are involved in brain plasticity. There are few functional or structural neuroimaging studies that investigated the neural correlates of switching handedness. Siebner and coworkers (2002), performed fMRI study during writing with the dominant hand (i. e. the hand normally used for writing by the tested subjects). The results showed the predominance of activation in left parietal and premotor regions in right-handers, and more bilateral activation with some activation foci in the right hemisphere (particularly in premotor, parietal and temporal areas) in switched left-handers. Moreover, there was a relationship between the degree of left hand dominance and cerebral blood flow in these right hemisphere regions. In the same research the brain activation pattern was also studied in consistent lefthanders; this pattern was characterized by a clear right hemisphere dominance (Siebner et al. 2002). The authors concluded that the presence of right-hemisphere activation in converted left- handers is there flection of not complete left-to right shift in handedness and still present motor control exerted by the right hemisphere.
Who was Julian of Norwich?
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old.

This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died.
Who was Julian of Norwich? In order to understand the figure and the message of this extraordinary English medieval mystic of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century we have to glimpse briefly the historical background in which she lived. The fourteenth century was a period of many great mystics and saints, like Angela of Foligno, Gertrude the Great, Christina of Stommeln, Raymond Lull, Margaret Ebner, Henry Suso, Lidwina of Schiedam, also Catherine of Sienna and Bridget of Sweden who struggled for the Reform of the Church and the Papacy. At the same time it was an unusually tumultuous age. The plague of the Black Death, the Great Schism and the Hundred Years’ War between the kings of France and England made of this period one of the darkest moments of the world and Church history. This general situation of suffering and confusion was present not only on the continent, but was deeply felt in England as well. The first wave of the Black Death came to Britain from the continent in 1348 when Julian was about six years old. Two further onslaughts followed in 1361 and 1369 when she was nineteen and twenty-six years old. The disease was so violent and contagious that nearly anyone who touched the sick became infected and died. A chronicler of that period reports that the priests who ministered to the dying, were put into the same grave with their penitents.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16).
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions.
With childlike simplicity and unwavering hope she comes to tell us that despite all evils God loves us and will make all things well again. In this way she succeeds in undermining the wide-spread belief of the time, namely, that disasters and wars come from God who, enraged by our sins, sends chastisements upon the world. Julian’s visions stand in complete opposition to this theology of God’s anger, reminding us of the basic truth of the biblical Revelation: God is love (1 Jn 4, 16). There is no doubt that Julian can be inserted into the long tradition of mystical theology that goes from St. Dionysius the Areopagite up to the unknown author of The Cloud of Unknowing. She is often compared to great medieval mystics, and in particular to St. Bridget of Sweden, the author of her own Revelations. There are also striking similarities between Julian’s Showings and the Interior Castle of St. Theresa of Avila: both of them speak of the human soul as a citadel or a castle in the centre of which God himself dwells. That is the reason why Julian can be regarded as one of the great pillars of western mysticism. Thomas Merton considers Julian and John Henry Newman, beatified by Benedict XVI on 19 September 2010, the greatest English theologians. Though Julian considers herself unlearned, Merton sees in her a true theologian, since she does not simply transmit what she experienced, but elaborates theologically the content of her visions. Finally, with her Showings of Love, as far as it unveils God’s motherly operation of mercy and compassion for the world, Julian can be seen as a fourteenth century precursor of St. Faustina Kowalska, the great harbinger of the Divine Mercy in the XX century.
With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital.
With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days.
With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine.
With other animals, you’re trying to give just enough anesthetic to immobilize them, but with a giraffe, we use a total overdose to chemically knock them off their feet,  the sun-leathered 59-year-old tells me as I stalk him stalking a two- year-old female giraffe somewhere in the Nigerien bush, about 60 miles east of Niamey, Niger’s capital. He is wearing a camo hat and a pair of torn, purple- checkered boxers that he’s been wearing as shorts for the past several days. Morkel has loaded his dart gun with a dose of etorphine, an opioid about 6, 000 times more powerful than morphine. Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying.

Once it penetrates the giraffe’s skin, he and his team will have just minutes to chase down the animal, tackle her, and inject her neck with an antidote to keep her from dying. If she can be successfully captured and survive a 500-mile translocation across Niger, she’ll become one of eight founding Adams and Eves of a new population of one of the world’s rarest wild mammals.

Samburu cattle herders found the abandoned calf and alerted Sarara—known for raising orphaned stmammals and returning them to their habitat.

The giraffes we have chased for a week are the descendants of some 50 animals that made their way to the West African country of Niger in the late 1980s, when drought and war pushed them from their habitat in neighboring Mali.

The giraffes we have chased for a week are the descendants of some 50 animals that made their way to the West African country of Niger in the late 1980s, when drought and war pushed them from their habitat in neighboring Mali. They walked south-southeast across the Sahel, along the Niger River, and skirted Niamey before settling in the Koure region, on a dry and dusty plateau.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. Movements were self-paced at a rate of approximately 2 Hz, which was comfortable for subjects and easy to control. All subjects practiced the two tasks prior to scanning to ensure similar task execution. The onset of each of the different tasks was signaled by the presentation of one of three differently colored squares presented on a rear-projection screen visible to subjects through a system of mirrors mounted in the scanner. A white square indicated the rest condition, a red square indicated the simple movement condition and a blue square indicated the complex movement condition.
Within each run the tasks were performed either with the right or the left hand. The order of left and right hand runs was randomized across subjects. The squares remained visible during each condition.

Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible.
Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life.
Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn.
Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind.
Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life.
Yet, Blomfield’s information is not thoroughly impossible. First of all, we do not have any solid contrary proofs against Julian’s old age and, secondly, Blomfield’s text does not exhibit any confusion of Julian, who was considered a person of great holiness, with another recluse who may have followed her way of life. There is another important witness to Julian’s historicity, given by her contemporary, Margery Kempe of King’s Lynn. She was also a mystic, but of a totally different cast of mind. Unlike Julian, who wanted to remain hidden and forgotten, Margery was a self- centred woman, always ready to extol her own personality, and too much preoccupied with extraordinary manifestations of the mystical life. She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment.

She tells us in her autobiography that she sought Julian out for advice in her cell, in about 1412 or 1413, since she was enjoying the fame of a well-known expert in spiritual guidance and discernment. Margery makes no mention of Julian’s book of Showings, yet the conversation that she recorded in her book reflects strikingly Julian’s theology of love.

Giraffe numbers have dropped by 40 percent in 30 years, to about 110, 000 in the wild.

Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression.

Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine.
Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead.

Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder.

And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction.

Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms.

And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things.
Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love.
Yet, once again, dopamine circuits are most likely involved. As the rejected partner comes to believe that the reward will never come, dopamine-producing cells in the reward system of the brain decrease their activity, producing lethargy, despondency, and depression. Short-term stress escalates the production of dopamine and norepinephrine. Long-term stress suppresses the activity of these neurochemicals, producing depression instead. Many professionals define addiction as a pathological, problematic disorder. And because romantic love is a positive experience under many circumstances, researchers remain largely unwilling to officially categorize romantic love as an addiction. But love addiction is just as real as any other addiction, in terms of its behavior patterns and brain mechanisms. Even when romantic love isn’t harmful, it is associated with intense craving and anxiety and can impel the lover to believe, say, and do dangerous and inappropriate things. Moreover, all forms of substance abuse, including alcohol, opioids, cocaine, amphetamines, cannabis, and tobacco (as well as the non-substance addictions to food, gambling, and sex) activate several of the same reward pathways that are activated among men and women who are happily in love, as well as those rejected in love. Unlike all other addictions, however, which afflict only a percentage of the population, some form of love addiction is likely to occur to almost every human being at some point during the life course.
